children.value: Predicting how long an algorithm will take to solve a particular problem, on a particular computer, as written in a particular way in a particular programming language, is an enormously difficult undertaking. It’s more practical to predict how the required time will scale as a function of the size of the problem. In the case of a linear system of equations, the problem size is

children.html: nnn

children.value: , the number of equations and variables in the system.  Because expressions of computational time are necessarily approximate, it’s customary to suppress all but the term that is dominant as

children.html: n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞

children.value: . We first need to build some terminology for these expressions.

children.value: It’s conventional to use asymptotic notation that is as specific as possible. For instance, while it is true that

children.html: n2+n=O(n10)n^2+n=O(n^{10})n2+n=O(n10)

children.value: , it’s more informative, and usually expected, to say

children.html: n2+n=O(n2)n^2+n=O(n^2)n2+n=O(n2)

children.value: . There are additional notations that enforce this requirement strictly, but we will just stick to the informal understanding.
There is a memorable way to use asymptotic notation to simplify sums:

children.label: sumflops
children.html: ∑k=1nk∼n22=O(n2), as n→∞,∑k=1nk2∼n33=O(n3), as n→∞,⋮∑k=1nkp∼np+1p+1=O(np+1), as n→∞.\begin{split} \sum_{k=1}^n k&\sim \frac{n^2}{2} = O(n^2), \text{ as $n\to\infty$}, \\ \sum_{k=1}^n k^2 &\sim \frac{n^3}{3} = O(n^3), \text{ as $n\to\infty$}, \\ &\vdots \\ \sum_{k=1}^n k^p &\sim \frac{n^{p+1}}{p+1} = O(n^{p+1}), \text{ as $n\to\infty$}. \end{split}k=1∑n​kk=1∑n​k2k=1∑n​kp​∼2n2​=O(n2), as n→∞,∼3n3​=O(n3), as n→∞,⋮∼p+1np+1​=O(np+1), as n→∞.​

children.value: Traditionally, in numerical linear algebra we count

for short. In our interpretation each scalar addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and square root counts as one flop. Given any algorithm, we simply add up the number of scalar flops and ignore everything else.
Here is a straightforward implementation of matrix-vector multiplication.

n = 6
A = randn(n, n)
x = rand(n)
y = zeros(n)
for i in 1:n
    for j in 1:n
        y[i] += A[i, j] * x[j]    # 1 multiply, 1 add
    end
end
Each of the loops implies a summation of flops. The total flop count for this algorithm is

children.html: ∑i=1n∑j=1n2=∑i=1n2n=2n2.\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n 2 = \sum_{i=1}^n 2n = 2n^2.i=1∑n​j=1∑n​2=i=1∑n​2n=2n2.
A\mathbf{A}A
n2n^2n2

children.value: elements, all of which have to be involved in the product, it seems unlikely that we could get a flop count that is smaller than

children.html: O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)

children.value: Let’s run an experiment with the built-in matrix-vector multiplication. Note that Julia is unusual in that loops have a variable scope separate from its enclosing code. Thus,
below means that inside the loop, the name
will take on each one of the values that were previously assigned to the vector
function attaches a new value to the end of a vector.

n = 1000:1000:5000
t = []
for n in n
    A = randn(n, n)  
    x = randn(n)
    time = @elapsed for j in 1:80; A * x; end
    push!(t, time)
end
The reason for doing multiple repetitions at each value of

children.html: nnn

children.value: in the loop above is to avoid having times so short that the resolution of the timer is significant.
Looking at the timings just for

n=4000n=4000n=4000

children.value: Here is a straightforward implementation of matrix-vector multiplication.

n = 6
A = random.rand(n, n)
x = ones(n)
y = zeros(n)
for i in range(n):
    for j in range(n):
        y[i] += A[i, j] * x[j]   # 2 flops
Each of the loops implies a summation of flops. The total flop count for this algorithm is

children.value: Let’s run an experiment with the built-in matrix-vector multiplication. We assume that flops dominate the computation time and thus measure elapsed time.

N = 400 * arange(1, 11)
t = []
print("  n           t")
for i, n in enumerate(N):
    A = random.randn(n, n)  
    x = random.randn(n)
    start = timer()
    for j in range(50): A @ x
    t.append(timer() - start)
    print(f"{n:5}   {t[-1]:10.3e}")
The reason for doing multiple repetitions at each value of

children.html: nnn

children.value: above is to avoid having times so short that the resolution of the timer is a factor.
Looking at the timings just for

children.html: n=2000n=2000n=2000
n=4000n=4000n=4000

randn(5,5)*randn(5);  # throwaway to force compilation

n = 400:200:6000
t = []
for n in n
    A = randn(n, n)  
    x = randn(n)
    time = @elapsed for j in 1:50; A * x; end
    push!(t, time)

Plotting the time as a function of

children.html: nnn

children.value: on log-log scales is equivalent to plotting the logs of the variables.

scatter(n, t, label="data", legend=false,
    xaxis=(:log10, L"n"), yaxis=(:log10, "elapsed time (sec)"),
    title="Timing of matrix-vector multiplications")
You can see that while the full story is complicated, the graph is trending to a straight line of positive slope. For comparison, we can plot a line that represents

children.html: O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)

children.value: growth exactly. (All such lines have slope equal to 2.)

children.value: It is not hard to find an exact formula for the sum, but we use

children.html: ∼n2\sim n^2∼n2

children.value: . After all, since flop counting is only an approximation of true running time, why bother with the more complicated exact expression? An analysis of backward substitution yields the same result.

children.html: n×nn\times nn×n

children.html: ∼n2\sim n^2∼n2

children.value: factorization, we have to admit that
is not written as economically as it could be. Recall from our motivating example in
that we zero out the first row and column of

children.html: A\mathbf{A}A

children.value: with the first outer product, the second row and column with the second outer product, and so on. There is no good reason to do multiplications and additions with values known to be zero, so we could replace lines 15–19 of

for k in 1:n-1
    U[k,k:n] = Aₖ[k,k:n]
    L[k:n,k] = Aₖ[k:n,k]/U[k,k]
    Aₖ[k:n,k:n] -= L[k:n,k]*U[k,k:n]'
end
We will use the following handy fact.

children.html: k≤nk\le nk≤n
n−k+1n-k+1n−k+1

children.value: Line 17 above divides each element of the vector
by a scalar. Hence the number of flops equals the length of the vector, which is

children.html: n−k+1n-k+1n−k+1

children.value: Line 18 has an outer product followed by a matrix subtraction. The definition
of the outer product makes it clear that that computation takes one flop (multiplication) per element of the result, which here results in

children.html: (n−k+1)2(n-k+1)^2(n−k+1)2

children.value: flops. The number of subtractions is identical.

children.label: gecount1

children.value: function instead of the purely instructive
The first time a function is invoked, there may be significant time needed to compile it in memory. Thus, when timing a function, run it at least once before beginning the timing.

lu(randn(3, 3));   # throwaway to force compilation

n = 400:400:4000
t = []
for n in n
    A = randn(n, n)  
    time = @elapsed for j in 1:12; lu(A); end
    push!(t, time)
end
We plot the timings on a log-log graph and compare it to

children.html: O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)

children.value: . The result could vary significantly from machine to machine, but in theory the data should start to parallel the line as

children.html: n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞

children.value:
scatter(n, t, label="data", legend=:topleft,
    xaxis=(:log10, L"n"), yaxis=(:log10, "elapsed time"))
plot!(n, t[end ]* (n/n[end]).^3, l=:dash, label=L"O(n^3)")

children.value:
from scipy.linalg import lu
N = arange(200, 2600, 200)
t = zeros(len(N))
for i, n in enumerate(N):
    A = random.randn(n,n)  
    start = timer()
    for j in range(5): lu(A)
    t[i] = timer() - start
We plot the timings on a log-log graph and compare it to

children.html: O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)

children.value: . The result could vary significantly from machine to machine, but in theory the data should start to parallel the line as

children.html: n→∞n\to\inftyn→∞

children.value: In practice, flops are not the only aspect of an implementation that occupies significant time. Our position is that counting flops as a measure of performance is a useful oversimplification. We will assume that
factorization (and as a result, the solution of a linear system of

children.html: nnn

children.value: equations) requires a real-world time that is roughly

children.html: O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)

children.value: . This growth rate is a great deal more tolerable than, say,

children.html: O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)

children.value: , but it does mean that for (at this writing)

children.html: nnn

children.value: greater than 10,000 or so, something other than general
factorization will have to be used.

children.value: matrix types cause specialized algorithms to be invoked by the backslash. Define

A = rand(1000,1000)
B = tril(A)
C = LowerTriangular(B)
b = rand(1000)
with the backslash solver, time how long it takes to solve the linear system
